title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – On a night where the final score told only a fraction of the story, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a masterpiece that transcended the game itself. The Houston Rockets’ 102-86 victory over the Chicago Bulls was merely the backdrop for a historic, singular performance by "The Dream," who dominated with a staggering 43-point, 22-rebound double-double.

From the opening tip, it was clear Olajuwon was operating on a different plane. He was an unstoppable force in the paint, a whirlwind of spin moves, drop-steps, and his signature "Dream Shake" that left Bulls defenders, including a young Tyson Chandler, grasping at air. Each possession was a clinic in footwork and finesse, as Olajuwon efficiently carved up one of the league's premier defenses. His 43 points were not just a number; they were a relentless, quarter-by-quarter assertion of will.

While Michael Jordan, who led the Bulls with 24 points, provided flashes of his brilliance, this night belonged exclusively to the Rockets' legend. Olajuwon’s 22 rebounds, many on the offensive glass, snuffed out any potential Chicago rallies and demoralized a team accustomed to being the intimidators. Clyde Drexler’s 19 points were a vital supporting score, but he was a witness like everyone else in The Summit.

In the end, the statistics were almost too gaudy to be real: 43 and 22. This was not just a win; it was a statement. Against the mighty Bulls, Hakeem Olajuwon delivered one of the most dominant individual performances of the era, a legendary feat of power and grace that will forever be etched in the annals of the game.
